'''Rishi Sunak'''{{efn|Pronounced {{IPAc-en|ˈ|r|ɪ|ʃ|i|_|ˈ|s|uː|n|æ|k|audio=Rishi Sunak Pronunciation.ogg}} {{respell|RISH|ee|_|SOO|nak}}.<ref name="Rishi-Collins English Dictionary 2023">{{cite web |date=6 June 2023 |title=rishi |url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/rishi |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210428052456/https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/rishi |archive-date=28 April 2021 |access-date=6 June 2023 |website=[[Collins English Dictionary]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Sunak |url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/sunak |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221025203727/https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/sunak |archive-date=25 October 2022 |access-date=25 October 2022 |website=[[Collins English Dictionary]]}}</ref>}} (born 12 May 1980) is a British politician who served as [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] from 2022 to 2024. He was [[Leader of the Conservative Party (UK)|Leader of the Conservative Party]] from October 2022 to November 2024. Following his defeat to [[Keir Starmer]]’s [[Labour Party (United Kingdom)|Labour Party]] in the [[2024 United Kingdom general election|2024 general election]], he became [[Leader of the Opposition (United Kingdom)|Leader of the Opposition]], serving in this role from July to November 2024. The first [[British Asian]] to hold those offices, he previously held two [[Cabinet of the United Kingdom|Cabinet]] positions under [[Boris Johnson]], latterly as [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] from 2020 to 2022. Sunak has been [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Richmond and Northallerton (UK Parliament constituency)|Richmond and Northallerton]], previously [[Richmond (Yorks) (UK Parliament constituency)|Richmond (Yorks)]], since 2015. Following the stepping down of [[Boris Johnson]] in 2023 and [[Theresa May]] in 2024, combined with [[South West Norfolk in the 2024 United Kingdom general election|the loss]] of [[Liz Truss]]'s seat, Sunak is the only former Prime Minister still remaining in the House of Commons.
<!--Early life, business career, early political career-->

Sunak was born in [[Southampton]] to parents of Indian descent who immigrated to Britain from East Africa in the 1960s. He was educated at [[Winchester College]], studied [[philosophy, politics and economics]] at [[Lincoln College, Oxford]], and earned a [[Master of Business Administration]] from [[Stanford University]] in California as a [[Fulbright Scholar]]. During his time at Oxford University, Sunak undertook an internship at [[Conservative Central Office]], and joined the Conservatives. After graduating, Sunak worked for [[Goldman Sachs]] and later as a partner at the [[hedge fund]] firms [[the Children's Investment Fund Management]] and [[Theleme Partners]]. Sunak was elected to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] at the [[2015 United Kingdom general election|2015 general election]]. As a [[backbencher]], Sunak supported the successful campaign for [[Brexit]] in the [[2016 United Kingdom European Union membership referendum|2016 European Union membership referendum]]. Sunak was appointed to the junior ministerial position of [[Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Local Government]] by [[Theresa May]] in 2019, and was appointed to the cabinet-attending role of [[Chief Secretary to the Treasury]] by Johnson in 2019.<!--Tenure as Chancellor of the Exchequer-->

In 2020, Sunak was promoted to Chancellor of the Exchequer. During [[Chancellorship of Rishi Sunak|his time in the position]], Sunak was prominent in the [[British government response to the COVID-19 pandemic|government's financial response]] to the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom|COVID-19 pandemic]] and its [[Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom|economic impact]], including the [[Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme|furlough]] and [[Eat Out to Help Out]] schemes, and was also prominent in the government's response to the [[2021–present United Kingdom cost-of-living crisis|cost-of living crisis]]. As chancellor, Sunak received high approval and popularity ratings in the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, although his popularity later declined amid the cost-of living crisis in 2022. He resigned as chancellor in July 2022 amid [[July 2022 United Kingdom government crisis|a government crisis]] that culminated in Johnson's resignation, and stood in the [[July–September 2022 Conservative Party leadership election|leadership election]] to succeed him. He received the most votes in each of the series of MP votes, but lost the members' vote to [[Liz Truss]]. After spending the duration of [[Truss's premiership]] on the backbenches, Sunak was elected unopposed in the [[October 2022 Conservative Party leadership election|leadership election]] to succeed Truss, who resigned amid another [[October 2022 United Kingdom government crisis|government crisis]]; aged 42 at the time he became prime minister, Sunak became the youngest prime minister since [[Robert Jenkinson, 2nd Earl of Liverpool|The Earl of Liverpool]] in 1812.
<!--Tenure as Prime Minister-->

During [[Premiership of Rishi Sunak|his premiership]], Sunak attempted to improve the economy and stabilise national politics. He outlined five key priorities: halving inflation, growing the economy, cutting debt, reducing [[National Health Service]] waiting lists, and stopping the illegal [[English Channel migrant crossings (2018–present)|small-boat crossings of the English Channel]] by enacting the [[Rwanda asylum plan]]. On foreign policy, Sunak authorised [[United Kingdom and the Russian invasion of Ukraine|foreign aid and weapons shipments]] to [[Ukraine]] in response to the [[Russian invasion of Ukraine|Russian invasion of the country]], and pledged support for [[Israel]] after the [[2023 Hamas-led attack on Israel|attacks]] which began the [[Israel–Hamas war]] whilst later calling for a ceasefire in the [[Israeli invasion of the Gaza Strip (2023–present)|Gaza Strip]]. He did not avert further unpopularity for the Conservatives, reflected in the party's poor performances in the [[2023 United Kingdom local elections|2023]] and [[2024 United Kingdom local elections|2024 local elections]]. Sunak called a general election for July 2024 despite being widely expected to call the election in the autumn; the Conservatives lost this election in a landslide to the opposition [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] led by [[Keir Starmer]], ending 14 years of Conservative government. 
<!--Post-premiership and legacy--> 

After leaving office, Sunak became Leader of the Opposition and remained Conservative leader for nearly four months while the [[2024 Conservative Party leadership election (UK)|leadership election]] to replace him took place, and formed a [[Shadow Cabinet of Rishi Sunak|shadow cabinet]]. He was succeeded by [[Kemi Badenoch]], his [[Shadow Secretary of State for Housing, Communities and Local Government|Shadow Housing Secretary]]. He also intends to remain as a backbench MP for the next five years.

The furlough scheme initially ran for three months and was backdated to 1 March. ==== Cost of living crisis and energy crisis ====
{{Main|2021–present United Kingdom cost-of-living crisis|2021 United Kingdom natural gas supplier crisis}}
[[File:Rishi Sunak Official Cabinet Portrait, September 2021 (cropped).jpg|left|thumb|upright=0.75|Official cabinet portrait, September 2021]]
Amid the rising [[2021–present United Kingdom cost-of-living crisis|cost of living]] and [[2021 United Kingdom natural gas supplier crisis|energy]] crises, Sunak intensified efforts to respond to the crisis in May 2022, with a £5 billion [[Windfall tax (United Kingdom)|windfall tax]] on energy companies to help fund a £15 billion support package for the public. The package included every household getting a £400 discount on energy bills, which would be in addition to a £150 council tax refund the government had already ordered. For about 8 million of the UK's lowest income households, a further £650 payment was announced. Additionally, pensioners or those with disability would qualify for extra payments, on top of the £550 that every household gets, and the £650 they would receive if they had a low income.<ref name="numbers">{{cite web |last1=Partington |first1=Richard |last2=Kirk |first2=Ashley |date=3 February 2022 |title=In numbers: what is fuelling Britain's cost of living crisis? |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/feb/03/in-numbers-britains-cost-of-living-crisis |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220203083943/https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/feb/03/in-numbers-britains-cost-of-living-crisis |archive-date=3 February 2022 |access-date=12 June 2022 |work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=The editorial board |date=27 May 2022 |title=A striking U-turn to alleviate the UK cost of living crisis |url=https://www.ft.com/content/05e49e39-a569-4346-88b9-4543ec9efbe1 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220527171709/https://www.ft.com/content/05e49e39-a569-4346-88b9-4543ec9efbe1 |archive-date=27 May 2022 |access-date=12 June 2022 |work=[[Financial Times]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Clinton |first=Jane |date=10 June 2022 |title=How will the £650 one-off payment be paid? ==== Budgets ====
{{Main|2020 United Kingdom budget|March 2021 United Kingdom budget|October 2021 United Kingdom budget}}
[[File:Budget_Day_2021_(51633616891).jpg|alt=Sunak in a dark blue suit standing in front of the black door of 11 Downing Street, holding a small red suitcase at arm's length.|thumb|Sunak holding the [[Red box (government)|budget box]] the day of the [[October 2021 United Kingdom budget|October 2021 budget]]]]Sunak presented his first budget, Delivering on Our Promises to the British People, on 11 March 2020. It was scheduled to be followed by another budget in the autumn, but in September 2020 he announced that budget would be scrapped because of the COVID-19 pandemic, stating "now is not the right time to outline long-term plans – people want to see us focused on the here and now".<ref>{{cite web |date=11 March 2020 |title=Budget 2020: Chancellor pumps billions into economy to combat coronavirus |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-51835306 |access-date=11 March 2020 |website=BBC News |quote=The chancellor will deliver another Budget in the Autumn, with measures aimed at preparing the UK economy for post-Brexit trading arrangements with the EU.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=Sep 23, 2020 |title=Covid crisis forces Autumn Budget to be scrapped |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-54267795 |access-date=Sep 23, 2020 |website=BBC News}}</ref> Instead, additional statements were given by the chancellor in both [[July 2020 United Kingdom summer statement|summer]] and [[September 2020 United Kingdom Winter Economy Plan|autumn]].

The Winter Economy Plan was delivered by Sunak on 24 September 2020. The purpose of the statement was to announce measures aimed at further helping to promote economic recovery following the impact of COVID-19. The plan aimed to further promote economic recovery while preserving jobs and businesses which were considered viable. After a [[The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) (No. 4) Regulations 2020|second lockdown in England]] on 31 October 2020, the programme was extended several times, until 30 September 2021.<ref>{{cite news |date=2 March 2021 |title=Furlough support scheme to be extended until September |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-56259094 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210302222210/https://www.bbc.com/news/business-56259094 |archive-date=2 March 2021 |access-date=2 March 2021 |publisher=BBC News}}</ref>

The July 2020 summer statement (also known as the coronavirus mini-budget) was delivered by Sunak on 8 July 2020. The purpose of the statement was to announce measures aimed at helping to promote economic recovery following the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The statement was delivered to the House of Commons, where Sunak unveiled a spending package worth £30bn. Concerns were subsequently raised by organisations including [[HM Revenue and Customs]] and the [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]] about the statement's impact, as well as its cost-effectiveness, while at least one major retailer declined to take advantage of a financial bonus scheme intended for rehiring employees placed on furlough during the pandemic.

In his March 2021 budget, Sunak emphasized the effect the COVID-19 pandemic has had on the economy, with 700,000 people losing their jobs, the economy shrinking by 10% (the largest fall in 300 years), and the highest borrowing outside wartime.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web |date=2021-03-03 |title=UK Budget 2021: the chancellor's speech in full |url=https://www.ft.com/content/2f1829d4-89e5-4b58-9394-28da615cc0ae |access-date=2021-03-04 |website=www.ft.com |language=en-GB}}</ref><ref name="Part">{{cite news |last1=Partington |first1=Richard |last2=Allegretti |first2=Aubrey |date=3 March 2021 |title=Rishi Sunak flags tax rises in budget as total Covid spending tops £400bn |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2021/mar/03/rishi-sunak-tax-rises-budget-total-covid-support-spending-tops-400bn |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210305182620/https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2021/mar/03/rishi-sunak-tax-rises-budget-total-covid-support-spending-tops-400bn |archive-date=5 March 2021 |access-date=6 March 2021 |work=The Guardian}}</ref> The budget included an increase in the rate of corporation tax from 19% to 25% in 2023, a five-year freeze in the tax-free personal allowance and the higher rate income tax threshold, and the extension of the furlough scheme until the end of September.<ref>{{cite web |date=4 March 2021 |title=Budget 2021: Key points at-a-glance |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-56266773 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210305192146/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-56266773 |archive-date=5 March 2021 |access-date=6 March 2021 |work=BBC News}}</ref> Sunak was the first Chancellor to raise the [[United Kingdom corporation tax|corporation tax rate]] since [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]]'s [[Denis Healey]] in 1974.<ref name="Part" />

In October 2021, Sunak made his third and final budget statement, which included substantial spending promises related to science and education.<ref>{{cite web |title=Autumn budget 2021: Rishi Sunak On 5 July 2022, Sunak and Javid resigned almost simultaneously amid a scandal surrounding the [[Chris Pincher scandal|sexual harassment allegations]] against [[Chris Pincher]], which arose after it was revealed that Johnson had promoted Pincher to the position of Deputy Chief Whip while knowing of the allegations beforehand.<ref>{{cite news |last=Cowburn |first=Ashley |date=5 July 2022 |title=Rishi Sunak resigns as chancellor in devastating blow to Boris Johnson |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/rishi-sunak-resigns-chancellor-boris-johnson-b2116399.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220705174013/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/rishi-sunak-resigns-chancellor-boris-johnson-b2116399.html |archive-date=5 July 2022 |access-date=6 July 2022 |work=The Independent}}</ref> Sunak was the second of 61 Conservative MPs to resign during the government crisis.<ref name="resign22">{{cite web |date=5 July 2022 |title=Sunak and Javid quit cabinet as PM admits Pincher mistake |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/uk-politics-62048657 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220705170956/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/uk-politics-62048657 |archive-date=5 July 2022 |access-date=5 July 2022 |publisher=BBC}}</ref> He was succeeded as chancellor by [[Nadhim Zahawi]]. Following the resignations of Sunak and Javid, numerous junior ministers and among the [[parliamentary private secretary]] (PPS) also resigned, most of whom cited a lack of honesty and integrity on the part of Johnson. In the following 24 hours, 36 MPs resigned from their roles in government and Johnson announced his resignation. In his resignation letter Sunak said:

{{Blockquote|text=The public rightly expect government to be conducted properly, competently and seriously. I recognise this may be my last ministerial job, but I believe these standards are worth fighting for and that is why I am resigning. It has become clear to me that our approaches are fundamentally too different. I am sad to be leaving Government but I have reluctantly come to the conclusion that we cannot continue like this.}}

=== Local election results ===
{{see also|2023 United Kingdom local elections|2024 United Kingdom local elections|Leadership approval opinion polling for the 2024 United Kingdom general election#Rishi Sunak}}
[[File:Prime Minister campaigns in Selby (53031710063).jpg|thumb|Sunak campaigning in July 2023]]Sunak was faced with the task of rebuilding the Conservatives' reputation which had been significantly damaged by the [[Premiership of Boris Johnson#Scandals|controversies and scandals of the previous year]] and the Truss ministry. While their poll ratings recovered slightly over the following months, it still wasn't enough to bring them back to pre-Truss levels. Sunak contested his first [[2023 United Kingdom local elections|local elections]] as leader on 4 May 2023, where the Conservatives suffered heavy losses. Two months later, on 20 July 2023, they lost two seats in by-elections; [[2023 Selby and Ainsty by-election|one]] to Labour and [[Somerton and Frome (UK Parliament constituency)|one]] to the Liberal Democrats. Their fortunes remained unchanged throughout policy changes of the following year, such as the shelving of the [[High Speed 2|HS2]] northern phase in October. The Conservatives lost two further seats in by-elections on 15 February 2024.

Most members of Sunak's cabinet heading into the 2024 general election were given the same portfolios in the shadow cabinet, including former chancellor Jeremy Hunt, who became [[Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer|shadow chancellor]], and former home secretary James Cleverly, who became [[Shadow Home Secretary|shadow home secretary]].<ref name=":03">{{Cite news |last=Craig |first=Jon |date=8 July 2024 |title=Sunak names shadow cabinet |url=https://news.sky.com/story/election-results-labour-keir-starmer-prime-minister-tory-reform-lib-dem-latest-news-12593360?postid=7943427 |access-date=8 July 2024 |work=Sky News}}</ref> Former foreign secretary David Cameron chose to retire from frontline politics, with his former deputy [[Andrew Mitchell]] becoming [[Shadow Secretary of State for Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Affairs|shadow foreign secretary]] instead.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Hymas |first=Charles |date=8 July 2024 |title=David Cameron to step back from frontline politics |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2024/07/08/politics-election-keir-starmer-tories-latest-news/#1720456456221 |access-date=8 July 2024 |work=The Telegraph}}</ref> Richard Holden resigned as [[Chairman of the Conservative Party|party chairman]], and was succeeded by [[Richard Fuller (Conservative politician)|Richard Fuller]] in an interim capacity outside shadow cabinet.<ref>{{Cite web |title=UK's Sunak appoints 'shadow' cabinet after historic election loss | Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/uks-sunak-appoints-shadow-cabinet-after-historic-election-loss-2024-07-08/ |website=[[Reuters]]}}</ref>

Sunak appointed new officeholders to the portfolios held by the eleven cabinet ministers who lost their seats in the election, including [[Edward Argar]], who became [[Shadow Secretary of State for Justice|shadow justice secretary]] after the outgoing justice secretary [[Alex Chalk]] lost his seat, as well as [[Helen Whately]], who became [[Shadow Secretary of State for Transport|shadow transport secretary]] after the outgoing transport secretary [[Mark Harper]] also lost his seat.<ref name="LBC2">{{Cite news |last=Kelly |first=Kieran |date=8 July 2024 |title=Richard Holden quits as Tory party chairman as Rishi Sunak unveils shadow cabinet |url=https://www.lbc.co.uk/news/richard-holden-quit-tory-party-chairman-rishi-sunak-shadow-cabinet/ |access-date=8 July 2024 |work=LBC News}}</ref> Among other noteworthy appointments, [[Kemi Badenoch]] became the [[Shadow Secretary of State for Housing, Communities and Local Government|shadow housing, communities and local government secretary]] and former deputy prime minister Oliver Dowden became [[Deputy Leader of the Opposition (United Kingdom)|deputy leader of the opposition]].<ref name="LBC2" /><ref name=":13">{{Cite news |last=Muvija |first=M. |date=8 July 2024 |title=UK's Sunak appoints 'shadow' cabinet after historic election loss |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/uks-sunak-appoints-shadow-cabinet-after-historic-election-loss-2024-07-08 |access-date=8 July 2024 |work=Reuters}}</ref>

Sunak remained leader until his successor, Kemi Badenoch, was elected in the [[2024 Conservative Party leadership election (UK)|2024 Conservative Party leadership election]],<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Courea |first1=Eleni |last2=Walker |first2=Peter |date=2024-07-05 |title=Rishi Sunak resigns as Tory leader as well as PM after election defeat |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/article/2024/jul/05/rishi-sunak-to-resign-as-tory-leader-as-well-as-pm-after-election-defeat |access-date=2024-07-05 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-07-04 |title=Rishi Sunak accepts responsibility for historic Tory defeat |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cd1xnzlzz99o |access-date=2024-07-05 |website=BBC News |language=en-GB}}</ref> after which he returned to the backbenches. Responding to the [[2024 State Opening of Parliament]], Sunak said his party would not oppose the government "for the sake of it", but would hold them to account on their election promises. On proposals to change planning laws, Sunak said that though such changes were needed "a system that does not allow local people to have a say will damage public consent for more housing in the long term".<ref name=Growth>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c903d09jwk7o |title=Starmer pledges growth with building and rail reforms |date=17 July 2024 |website=BBC News |publisher=BBC |accessdate=17 July 2024}}</ref> While he respected Starmer's decision to scrap the Rwanda asylum plan, Sunak said that there needed to be an alternative deterrent, otherwise "a large number of those who crossed the Channel illegally will end up remaining here".<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hardman |first=Isabel |date=2024-07-17 |title=Rishi Sunak looks much happier in opposition |url=https://www.spectator.co.uk/article/rishi-sunak-looks-much-happier-in-opposition/ |access-date=2024-07-22 |website=The Spectator |language=en-US}}</ref>
